title: 111_hr3901
content: The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" enhances the administration of the first-time homebuyer tax credit. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" amends the age limitation for the tax credit, requiring taxpayers to be at least 18 years old at the time of purchasing a residence. Additionally, documentation requirements are updated under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" updates documentation requirements for the first-time homebuyer tax credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It includes provisions such as the taxpayer failing to attach a properly executed copy of the settlement statement to the tax return and restrictions on married individuals acquiring a residence from the family of their spouse. Additionally, errors related to claiming the tax credit are treated as mathematical or clerical errors. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" updates documentation requirements for the first-time homebuyer tax credit by adding new conditions for claiming the credit, including age requirements, consistency of information on tax returns, and attaching necessary forms. These amendments apply to the tax credit provisions. The amendments made by the "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" apply to purchases after the enactment date, with documentation requirements for taxable years ending after that date. Mathematical and clerical errors amendments apply to returns for taxable years ending on or after April 9, 2008. Certain tax return preparers are required to file returns electronically. Certain tax return preparers are required to file returns electronically. Subsection (e) of section 6011 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to require individual income tax returns prepared by tax return preparers to be filed on magnetic media if the preparer is a specified tax return preparer for the calendar year and expects to file more than 100 returns. The amendment requires tax return preparers to file individual income tax returns electronically if they expect to file more than 100 returns in a calendar year. The effective date for these changes is after December 31, 2010.
